t3.title: Adding space to a tenant device
t3.keywords: SERVICED_DM_BASESIZE serviced serviced serviced serviced serviced Volume-Group-Name serviced Volume-Group-Name serviced serviced Size serviced Volume-Group-Name serviced Size Volume-Group-Name Volume-Group-Name serviced Tenant-Device-ID Total-Device-Size Volume-Group-Name Tenant-Device-ID Total-Device-Size

t4.title: Backing up and restoring
t4.desc:
Use Control Center to back up applications that Control Center manages.
    Having accurate and tested system backups can mitigate problems caused by software or hardware
    issues. The Control Center backup process creates a compressed tar archive file
      (.tgz) that can be restored on the same cluster or a similar
    cluster.

t5.title: Best practices for backup and restore
t5.desc:
Review considerations and best practices that apply to application backup and
    restore.

t6.title: Backing up using the browser interface
t6.desc: Using the browser interface, you can create a backup of your entire system.

t7.title: Backing up using the CLI
t7.desc:
As an alternative to performing application backup from the Control Center
    browser interface, you can use the command-line interface (CLI).

t9.title: Exclude one tenant volume from the backup

t10.title: Exclude multiple tenant volumes from the backup

t11.title: Restoring from a backup
t11.desc:
Restore an instance of an application from a backup file on the same system, or restore
    from a backup file to duplicate an instance on a new, similarly configured cluster.

t12.title: Snapshot and rollback
t12.desc:
Though backups are the most reliable and durable way to preserve Docker images and
    configurations, creating a backup of an entire application is not always practical. However, you
    need to safeguard against potential risk when changing the system. In these cases, you can
    create a snapshot of the system.

t13.title: Creating a snapshot

t25.title: serviced backup
t25.desc:
The serviced backup command saves a snapshot of the current state of
    the system, the state of all services, and application data to a compressed tar archive file
      (.tgz).

t26.title: serviced docker
t26.desc:
The serviced docker command administers Docker images and
    registry.
t26.keywords: serviced docker serviced docker serviced docker

t27.title: serviced pool
t27.desc:
The serviced pool command administers Control Center resource
    pool data.
t27.keywords: serviced pool serviced pool serviced pool set-permission POOLID --admin CommandOptions POOLID

t28.title: serviced restore
t28.desc:
The serviced restore command restores an instance of an application
    from a backup file on the same system. You can also duplicate your instance on a similar cluster
    for testing or failover purposes by restoring a backup file to a new, similarly configured
    cluster.

t29.title: serviced script
t29.desc:
The serviced script command verifies or performs the commands in a
    script file.

t30.title: serviced service
t30.desc:
The serviced service command lets you manage an application's
    individual services.

t31.title: serviced snapshot
t31.desc:
The serviced snapshot command administers environment
    snapshots.
